docs.title: 🚀 Enable/Update and Disable GH-Pages
docs.text: See GitHub Pages Tool

docs.title: 📦️ Install Package and Dependencies
docs.text:
Note: This will also do a Jupyter nbconvert to notebook

./pyinstall.sh

docs.title: 👨‍💻 MKDocs Cli
docs.text:
bash
./mkdocs --help

docs.title: GitHub Pages Management Tool
docs.text:
This Go-based command-line tool allows you to enable, update, or disable GitHub Pages for a repository. By leveraging the GitHub API, the tool simplifies the management of GitHub Pages configurations, providing the following functionalities:

  • Enable GitHub Pages: Set up GitHub Pages for the repository with a specified branch and path.
  • Update GitHub Pages: Modify the existing GitHub Pages setup, changing the branch or path.
  • Disable GitHub Pages: Disable GitHub Pages for the repository.

The tool interacts with GitHub via the go-github library, making it easy to integrate into your workflows, automate repository configurations, and manage Pages without manually editing settings on GitHub.

docs.title: 📌 Dependencies
docs.text: • golang 1.24

docs.title: 🏗️ Build
docs.text: cd bin && go build .

docs.title: 🧑‍💻 Usage
docs.text:
📌 NOTE

Run from the bin directory 

Usage:
    ./mkdocs-ghpages <enable|update|disable> <owner> <repo> <token> [branch] [path]

docs.title: Advanced Examples
docs.text:
In [1]: Copied! 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
y = np.sin(x)

plt.plot(x, y)
plt.title("Sine Wave")
plt.xlabel("x")
plt.ylabel("sin(x)")
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import numpy as np x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100) y = np.sin(x) plt.plot(x, y) plt.title("Sine Wave") plt.xlabel("x") plt.ylabel("sin(x)") plt.grid(True) plt.show() In [2]: Copied! 
import pandas as pd

data = {
    "Name": ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"],
    "Score": [88, 92, 95],
    "Passed": [True, True, True]
}

df = pd.DataFrame(data)
df
import pandas as pd data = { "Name": ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"], "Score": [88, 92, 95], "Passed": [True, True, True] } df = pd.DataFrame(data) df Out[2]: Name Score Passed 0 Alice 88 True 1 Bob 92 True 2 Charlie 95 True In [3]: Copied! 
import ipywidgets as widgets
from IPython.display import display

slider = widgets.IntSlider(value=5, min=1, max=10, step=1, description='Slider:')
display(slider)
import ipywidgets as widgets from IPython.display import display slider = widgets.IntSlider(value=5, min=1, max=10, step=1, description='Slider:') display(slider) In [4]: Copied! 
from IPython.display import HTML

HTML("""
<div style='padding: 1em; background: #f4f4f4; border-left: 4px solid #007acc;'>
  <strong>Info:</strong> This is a custom HTML block.
</div>
""")
from IPython.display import HTML HTML(""" Info: This is a custom HTML block. """) Out[4]: Info: This is a custom HTML block.

docs.title: 🧠 Math Rendering (LaTeX-style)¶
docs.text: You can render mathematical expressions using LaTeX syntax: $$\int_0^\infty e^{-x^2} dx = \frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2}$$

docs.title: example_python_reference.calculator
docs.text:
simple_math.calculator

A simple calculator module for basic arithmetic operations.

docs.title: add(a, b)
docs.text:
Add two numbers.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default a float

The first number.

required b float

The second number.

required

Returns:

Type Description float

The sum of a and b.

Examples:

>>> add(1, 2)
3.0
Source code in .venv/lib/python3.11/site-packages/example_python_reference/calculator.py 
def add(a: float, b: float) -> float:
    """
    Add two numbers.

    Parameters
    ----------
    a : float
        The first number.
    b : float
        The second number.

    Returns
    -------
    float
        The sum of a and b.

    Examples
    --------
    >>> add(1, 2)
    3.0
    """
    return float(a + b)

docs.title: divide(a, b)
docs.text:
Divide one number by another.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default a float

The numerator.

required b float

The denominator.

required

Returns:

Type Description float

The result of a / b.

Raises:

Type Description ZeroDivisionError

If b is zero.

Examples:

>>> divide(10, 2)
5.0
Source code in .venv/lib/python3.11/site-packages/example_python_reference/calculator.py 
def divide(a: float, b: float) -> float:
    """
    Divide one number by another.

    Parameters
    ----------
    a : float
        The numerator.
    b : float
        The denominator.

    Returns
    -------
    float
        The result of a / b.

    Raises
    ------
    ZeroDivisionError
        If b is zero.

    Examples
    --------
    >>> divide(10, 2)
    5.0
    """
    if b == 0:
        raise ZeroDivisionError("Division by zero is not allowed.")
    return float(a / b)

docs.title: multiply(a, b)
docs.text:
Multiply two numbers.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default a float

The first number.

required b float

The second number.

required

Returns:

Type Description float

The product of a and b.

Examples:

>>> multiply(2, 4)
8.0
Source code in .venv/lib/python3.11/site-packages/example_python_reference/calculator.py 
def multiply(a: float, b: float) -> float:
    """
    Multiply two numbers.

    Parameters
    ----------
    a : float
        The first number.
    b : float
        The second number.

    Returns
    -------
    float
        The product of a and b.

    Examples
    --------
    >>> multiply(2, 4)
    8.0
    """
    return float(a * b)

docs.title: subtract(a, b)
docs.text:
Subtract one number from another.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default a float

The number to subtract from.

required b float

The number to subtract.

required

Returns:

Type Description float

The result of a - b.

Examples:

>>> subtract(5, 3)
2.0
Source code in .venv/lib/python3.11/site-packages/example_python_reference/calculator.py 
def subtract(a: float, b: float) -> float:
    """
    Subtract one number from another.

    Parameters
    ----------
    a : float
        The number to subtract from.
    b : float
        The number to subtract.

    Returns
    -------
    float
        The result of a - b.

    Examples
    --------
    >>> subtract(5, 3)
    2.0
    """
    return float(a - b)
